intro: Solanum anghivi, commonly known as the black nightshade, is a herbaceous plant belonging to the nightshade family (Solanaceae). It is native to regions of Africa, the Middle East, and parts of Asia, often found in disturbed soils and arid environments. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with hairy stems and alternate, ovate leaves. Its small, violet to black berries are its most distinctive feature, containing toxic compounds such as solanine. Despite its toxicity, it has been used in traditional medicine for various purposes, though caution is necessary due to its harmful effects.
